criteria: Explanation of how Internal Influences lead to/prevent Injury or Violence
Explanation of how External Influences lead to/prevent Injury or Violence
descriptions: Student does not identify any internal influences on injury or violence.
Student identifies one internal influence with limited accuracy or detail.
Student identifies two internal influences with basic accuracy.
Student identifies three internal influences with reasonable accuracy and some detail.
Student identifies multiple internal influences with good accuracy and clear examples.
Student comprehensively identifies and explains various internal influences, providing insightful examples and demonstrating a strong understanding.
Student does not explain how internal influences affect injury or violence.
Student offers a vague or unclear explanation of the relationship between internal influences and injury/violence.
Student provides a basic explanation of how one or two internal influences can lead to or prevent injury/violence.
Student explains how multiple internal influences can lead to or prevent injury/violence, with some supporting details.
Student clearly and accurately explains the mechanisms by which internal influences increase or decrease the risk of injury/violence, providing relevant examples.
Student provides a sophisticated and nuanced explanation of the complex interplay between internal influences and the likelihood of injury/violence, demonstrating critical thinking.
Student does not identify any external influences on injury or violence.
Student identifies one external influence with limited accuracy or detail.
Student identifies two external influences with basic accuracy.
Student identifies three external influences with reasonable accuracy and some detail.
Student identifies multiple external influences with good accuracy and clear examples.
Student comprehensively identifies and explains various external influences, providing insightful examples and demonstrating a strong understanding.
Student does not explain how external influences affect injury or violence.
Student offers a vague or unclear explanation of the relationship between external influences and injury/violence.
Student provides a basic explanation of how one or two external influences can lead to or prevent injury/violence.
Student explains how multiple external influences can lead to or prevent injury/violence, with some supporting details.
Student clearly and accurately explains the mechanisms by which external influences increase or decrease the risk of injury/violence, providing relevant examples.
Student provides a sophisticated and nuanced explanation of the complex interplay between external influences and the likelihood of injury/violence, demonstrating critical thinking.
